1. In a small survey, a random sample of 50 people from a large population is selected. 
Each person is asked a question to which the answer is either Yes" or No." Let the 
proportion in the population who would answer Yes" be ğœƒ. Our prior distribution 
for ğœƒ is a ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡ğ‘(1.5, 1.5) distribution. In the survey, 37 people answer â€œYes.". 
Use R to:
i) Find prior probability that ğœƒ < 0.6 equals 0.62647.
```{r}
library(LearnBayes)
library(HDInterval)

pbeta(0.6,1.5,1.5)#PRIOR PROBABILITY
```
ii) Plot a graph showing the prior and posterior probability density functions of ğœƒ
on the same axes.
```{r}
#plotting a graph showing the prior and posterior probability
theta<-seq(0.01,0.99,0.01)
prior0<-dbeta(theta,1.5,1.5)
par(mfrow=c(1,2))
data<-c(37,13)
posterior<-dbeta(theta,37,13)
plot(theta,posterior,ylab="density")
triplot(prior0,data,where="topright")
```
2. The numbers of sales of a particular item from an Internet retail site in each of 20 
weeks are recorded. Assume that, given the value of a parameter ğœ†, these numbers 
are independent observations from the Poisson (ğœ†) distribution. Our prior 
distribution for ğœ† is a gamma (a, b) distribution. Suppose prior mean and standard 
deviation for ğœ† are 16 and 8 respectively. The observed numbers of sales are as 
follows.
14, 19, 14, 21, 22, 33, 15, 13, 16, 19, 27, 22, 27, 21, 16, 25, 14, 23, 22, 17

```{r}
#plotting both prior and posterior probability density function
sales<-c(14,19,14,21,22,33,15,13,16,19,27,
         22,27,16,25,14,23,22,17)
lambda<-seq(10,25,0.05)
prior<-dgamma(lambda,4,0.25)

```

find a 95% posterior HPD interval for ğœ†.
```{r}

```
